Looking at the GS analyst comment, they are worried about the market concentration in top 10 stocks and the high multiple PE. So their projection is SP equal weighted index will grow at 8 and capweighted at 3. Their analysis is that market will adjust to lower multiple as we see realistically normal growth and not the high growth values given to these companies. The higher PE is a concern, as long as you think growth is linear. Growth is always slightly exponential, unless interrupted by war or large natural calamity. But now, I think we are going to see an exponential growth in top companies which will make bring the multiples down or which justify the higher multiples. We cannot compare it with historical data without accounting for the increasing growth rate. And the large concentration in top company may look strange, till you compare the world now and 2030 years back. The large companies today are more global than ever and have a bigger slice of overall activity in the world anyone looking for information, today does google search, whereas 20 years back he was going to different libraries and publications. Every companys datacenter is today concentrated into 4 cloud companies, so these cloud companies are going to be big part of economy and hence market. In this current time, concentration allows growth acceleration. However technology and market are changing so rapidly that concentration in market no longer means you have to be less competitive or survive in slower growth mode. With AI tech, we will see a growth acceleration that we have not seen since internet. In a decade. Productivity will be 3x of current, if not more. And the next AI companies will control an even bigger part of the overall work and hence the market. And the growth will be much faster than anything we have ever seen. And market will respond to higher growth by going higher. Ofcourse more money infusion into market, due to higher deficit will drive this number higher. IMHO, we will see atleast 1315 SP growth, but more likely 17 or higher.

The insurance for the waste is one of the biggest prohibitions to nuclear waste. It essentially needs to be guaranteed forever, this results in the only ones willing to take the risk being states and countries.

It is not 75000 years to store waste. Low and intermediate level waste is stored for 30 years in cooldown pools before being buried is ceramic pucks, and hight level waste is stored for 50 years before being buried. High level waste loses 99.9 of its reactivity in 40 years. The worst high level waste is back to background level within 100010000 years. The Navy has stored all of its waste generated over the last 60 years of nuclear power in a single spent copper mine. 95 of waste is low level. 0.2 is high level, with intermediate making up the difference. 30 percent of all used fuel is reprocessed for reuse in reactors and a small percentage is refined for medical use. As for the cost. Long term storage for is estimated 10 of the total cost of the reactors lifetime expense, and is required by the government to be set aside to cover all costs.

Nuclear waste is an extremely over exagerated problem. The entirety of highly dangerous nuclear waste produced in France from the past 40 years fits into a single cube with sides measuring 15 meters. And Its the most nuclearized country in the world, and the total amount of carbon free energy produced for so little waste is absolutely outstanding.

Fat cats just didnt have the time to get the fuel so we were told solar and other bullshit is the way. Wut? Nuke was killed by NIMBYism. The fear of another Chernobyl, TMI, etc... forced the industry to be regulated to the point that for most companies it wasnt financially viable. The company I work for used to own Talen energy mentioned in this article the reason it was sold off is because it was just dead weight back then. Perfect example...at the Susquehanna plant mentioned, we had to keep two fleets of excavators on hand in case of a meltdown and pay for upkeep, maintenance, etc... It was literally redundancy for a black swan event, wild. This is the reason that Exelon has basically been the name in the game in nuke generation in the US. My old boss used to head up exelons nuke operations the only way they were able to make it profitable was through acquisition and absolutely ruthless standardization...they acquired a new plant and would implement the playbook...execsemployees who pushed back were gone. Same service intervals, same vendors for IT systems, same schemes, same excavator, same everything across the entire fleet. My company, as many others have long said nuke is the answer...with reasonable regulation. SMR and the involvement of big tech is bringing that conversation to the forefront. Nuke and nuke adjacent industries like utilities are great play at the moment. Same with NG, but thats a whole other discussion.

I mean its not hard to blame them for such fears when the consequences of just one mistake at a nuclear plant could be catastrophic. A lot of people are NIMBYs when it comes to nuclear energy, its great to have the energy it produces, but not to have a nuclear plant in their backyard where theyd suffer the fallout of another Chernobyl. On top of that, the fact is the more you engage in a risky activity the greater the odds of something bad happening from said activity even if the odds are really really low. i.e. the average driver could correctly boast having a 100 safety record, but obviously youd rightly laugh in their face if they insisted that means theres zero chance that theyll ever get into a car accident. Even if you have a bunch of very safe drivers on the road, the more very safe drivers you have on the road the greater the odds that one of those very safe drivers will get into an accident, it happens every day because theres millions of them on the road. That above paragraph isnt fear mongering about nuclear energy, its statistical odds.

Your fallacy is in attributing the causes of previous nuclear incidents all to operator error. Humans make mistakes, of course, and Chernobyl management was definitely negligent and reckless. However, what made Chernobyl a disaster was shoddy reactor design that wouldve never been possible in the West. I mean, hitting the shutdown reactor button is what caused the Chernobyl reactors to explode! Same goes to Fukushima with its backup generator design and way too tiny tsunami seawalls. Its not just the Wests operational practices that have made nuclear energy so safe here. Its that reactor facilities have been designed with passive safety in mind to prevent operator error from ever causing a disaster, and the next generation nuclear technology takes that to another level. Its like saying cars in the 50s were so dangerous because even minor accidents could kill or cause severe injury, so people just shouldnt drive. Sure, operators need to improve, but the cars themselves could get a whole lot safer, and they have!

when the consequences of just one mistake at a nuclear plant could be catastrophic. replies.text: Seems like there was a pretty strong majority wanting the 50bp cut. Not particularly divided, just not in perfect agreement. They may have used the weak jobs report as an argument to favour the 50bp cut against those who are more hesitant but I doubt it was the deciding factor. The fact is inflation is pretty spot on where they would hope it would be. They wouldnt want it to be much lower right now, otherwise the risk of overshooting would look to great, with high interest rates still likely pressuring inflation downwards, with the effect lagging. The better than expected jobs report since shouldnt change their course of action as long as inflation continues to come in in line with expectations. The balancing act theyre trying to pull off is working out perfectly for them so far, and pausing cuts due to a healthy economy with inflation in the target range would make very little sense. They would be shooting themselves in the foot. Theyre just as aware of the risk of deflation and recession. Theyre close to pulling off their dream scenario

Powell forcing through a jumbo cut right before a massive jobs beats and hot wages... Market pricing before the leak to WSJ Nick Timiraos was 0 for a 50bp move... Hard to argue this was not a politicized move. Sure it could end up being right. But it is hard to argue the Fed is data dependent when they ignore the data. Edit I wrote before. The responding comment makes no sense.
Rumors have it, the Fed will NOT cut rates!!!
They may have cut rates but I still am not seeingfeeling any relief on my end.

Theres some lunatics in there like Bowman and Bostic that just want to see the world burn. Luckily the median of the Fed board is fairly reasonable. But its not gonna stop the loons from speaking their opinion.
The report cites substantial which doesnt sound like pretty strong majority. It sounds like multiple governors were against a 50bp and were forced to agree to the jumbo cut.
You cant ignore future data, my friend. It hadnt happened yet.
Have you ever thought that feeling the effect of rate cuts take time?
no shot you thought a rate cut would improve your individual life for no apparent reason a month in

9 people wanted 3 cuts total or less in 2024, which means they wouldve favored a 25 bps cut in Sept. Theres really no good reason to start with 50 bps cut, and then not cut at all in 1 out of the next 2 meetings. Cutting by an extra 25 bps 1.5 months early is not gonna make or break the economy, but it creates a huge inconsistent image if you start with 50 bps and then pause the next. Most of the 3 cuts people were probably pressed by Powell to not dissent on the vote. Otherwise, 919 dissents wouldve looked bad, and Trump wouldve shredded the Fed to pieces. 10 people wanted 4 cuts or more total in 2024. The median is more divided than you think.

If they cut too soon inflation will reaccelerate. Probably not immediately but in a year or so. Cutting too soon just makes things worse for everyone in the long run, and promotes economic inefficiency by allowing inefficient businesses access to lower rate loans.
Did you even read my comment? I wrote before.

The data happened before the meeting, hence the 0 pricing of 50bp jumbo cut on Monday before meeting. Powell then leaked his decision to Timiraos at WSJ. I didnt suggest somehow the Fed could know the future data, just that the data they had convinced the market the Fed wouldnt do 50bp jumbo cut. CPI beat, unemployment rate fell, jobless claims fell.
I mean, sure. I just wanted them to take less time Im not even close to a financial expert, I dont understand how these things work. It was an idle comment about my reality.

no shot you thought a rate cut would improve your individual life for no apparent reason a month in LOL. Youre surprised some random person on the internet had a dumb ideahope? But if youre asking for the reason. I was fantasizing about refinancing my home loan the instant JPow published the press release.
The Fed clearly thought that by squeezing in an extra 25 bps 1.5 months early, during the blackout period when they could not communicategive forward guidance to the market.

Theres a very good reason to cut a half point and then pause in one of the next two meetings if you feel you should have cut in July, but are behind the curve. The Fed is constantly adapting to changing data. And all the recent data points to strong economy the recent jobs report was insanely bullish, so I certainly could see them pausing, particularly given their historical hawkishness. Although quarter point is also possible. I think the most likely scenario is two quarter point cuts. As far as where the median lies, I dont understand your math. There arent 19 relevant people in the Fed. Nonvoters opinions dont matter they can talk all they want, but they dont set policy. The 12 votes that matter are here You can somewhat assume the 4 hawkish dots in the June dotplot are likely Bowman, Schmid, Bostic, and Kashkari. Of those, two are voting this year, and two are voting next year. So at best worst?, 2 of the 12 voting members of the Fed are effectively not in favor of cutting much further. Moreover, the 2025 Fed voting picture gets even more dovish since it brings in Goolsbee...youre going to have 4 doves, 2 hawks, and a middle that slides a bit more dovish.
Well... thats actually reasonable, disregard

Theres very little difference between JulySeptDec cut and SeptNovDec cut. Like I said, 25 bps 1.5 months late doesnt mean much on the real economy. Their dot plots were done before the strong data. That means they thought 5.5 was obviously way too high to warrant starting with 50 bps cut, but then 5.0 is somehow not that high to even warrant a cut? When youre talking about Fed medians, Im assuming youre talking about all officials. Among 2024 voters and 9 people who put in 3 cuts in 2024, Bowman, Bostic, Barkin, and Waller wouldve all preferred a 25 bps cut. Hammack was a voter, but no clear side from her yet. I was talking about Sept dot plot, not June dot plot. I dont know why youre bringing up June dot plot to describe voters in Sept. Also, that dovehawk spectrum is pretty wrong by the way. Kashkari has turned back into a dove already and thinks the risk shifts more towards weaker labor market. Barkin is the third most hawkish Fed member behind Schmid. Dalys a dove, and Wallers much more hawkish than Powell, who is now pretty much a dove. In fact, Waller probably sets the tone for where the hawks stand, which was why the Sept vote was very surprising because the Friday before the blackout period, Waller came out and didnt give forward guidance for a 50 bps cut, which caused even the most dovish forecasters like Citi to move to predicting 25bps cut. For 2025, you get Goolsbee but loses Daly. You get Collins which is pretty much centrist, and Hammack is unknown. Loses Bostic but gets Schmid, so its pretty much the same as 2024.

lol, Kashkari changing his view on cuts literally in just the last month or two doesnt make him a dove...hes been plastered on the moar hikes bandwagon practically all year hes on the record as saying rate hikes arent off the table as late as May 28th If anything, the fact hes acquiesced to cuts and significant ones at that is more of a sign of how much sentiment has shifted, even among the hawks. Whereas nothing is perfect, I found that cheat sheet to be relatively accurate. Daly isnt a dove...in fact, Ive seen Daly go back and forth quite a few times in sentiment, very similar to Powell and Williams, both of whom are fairly rated in the middleish. They all tend to be reactive more than proactive. The fact you call Powell a dove is nuts. If he was a dove, they would have cut a quarter point in June when they should have. Hes _very_ clearly more weighted towards overvaluing the inflation side of their dualmandate. Waller may be a _touch_ too dovish on the chart, but marginally...hes nowhere near the Kashkari range. Hes probably somewhere between Barkin and Bostic. At that rate, youre really splitting hairs though. For 2025, I still disagree. Losing Daly, who is close to the middle, is not the same as gaining Goolsbee. When it comes down to it, I kinda view it like the Supreme Court...BowmanBosticSchmidKashkari are your AlitoThomases...you know what theyre going to do before they vote. Kugler, Barr, Goolsbee, and Cook are like Sotomayor...you know what theyre going to do before they vote. Everybody else is somewhere around the Roberts area...their opinions are going to ebb and flow based on prevailing data Daly being in that crosssection. Gaining a Goolsbee and losing a Daly is a distinct dovish shift...its a shift from a situational dove to a definite dove.

Did anyone else on the Fed say the risk is more weighted towards weaker labor market? None. Therefore, Kashkari is NOW a dove. I dont care what he said 12 months ago, because were talking about the present. If you want to talk about the past, why stop at 12 months. Go back 6 years, when he was the most dovish member. If you listened to Daly talk at all, youd see she clearly shifts more towards protecting the labor market. Shes a labor economist by training, and frequently talks about the hardship of lower class workers. Of course shes gonna lean towards protecting the labor market, which hits the lower class the most in recessions. Powell is CLEARLY a dove now. Look at his Jackson Hole speech. He was obviously pressuring the hawks in the committee towards a cut. Whenever Powell speaks at the FOMC or Jackson Hole, he has to represent the whole community, not just his own opinion. The fact that he declared definitively the Fed was cutting when several hawks were still on the fence, and then chimed in his own dovish opinions on a platform where he was representing the whole committee hawks and doves showed he was trying to steer the committee towards him. Even in July FOMC before the weak job report, you could see he was leaning towards a cut when the labor market was supposedly super strong, but couldnt convince the committee to get on board. Hes been itching to cut since July, easily just a notch below Goolsbee, and thats only because he has to represent the whole committee. Barkin is just as hawkish as Kashkari 6 months ago. He rarely talks about inflation progress, and is always cautious that businesses have shifted towards raising price first mindset. He doesnt even want to go back to neutral rate yet, which means he still thinks the risk leans towards higher inflation. In fact, they were frequently among the most hawkish dot plots along with BullardMesterBowman, and BosticWaller 1 notch below them. Waller was always saying the labor market is strong and theres no rush to cut in all his speech. No one knows what Barr will do. Barr doesnt talk about the economy much. He pretty much just follows Powell.

You have a point on Kashkari at the 6 year window. That was a radical change. Although I still dont believe hes currently a dove. Or at least we dont have enough data to show that. Like I said, he was talking a hawkish game literally 4 months ago and has been one of the most hawkish Fed officials for several years running now. I mean hes pretty much a hawkish meme on the internet with his crazy eyes. Is it possible his view radically shifted again? Absolutely. But I dont believe it yet. On Powell, I still disagree. His talk didnt talk dovish until after the June jobs report, when it became club over the head obvious to everyone Kashkari included. Powell talked very hawkish up to the point, including in his response to questions at the FOMC. In general, looking back at the FOMC meets, he would very easily dismiss weakening labor market news and trends and be very quick to latch onto even a subtle shift in inflation numbers. Like inflation would have 1 month of surprise upsurge and he would insist they need 3 more months of good inflation data before they can think of cutting. And if another upsurge happened in those 3 months, hed reset the 3 month counter. That went on nearly all year, fully ignorant of the trendline. And the inverse was true of jobs. Like you would see this clear upward trend in unemployment that he would fully ignore, pointing to the fact it went down in like a single recent report. I could very easily see Powell looking at the recent 254k jobs report, freaking out, and returning to his hawkish talk needing more data, having plenty of time to wait, pausing w tools to respond. Thats his MO...overreact to a single recent event and be slow to react to broader trends. At any rate, agree to disagree on this one, but you have fair points.

You have pretty outdated views. Powell had shifted away from his hawkish stance for almost a year now. He chose to signal a rate cut in Dec 2023 when financial condition was already overpricing Fed cuts, and after financial condition had loosened a lot a month prior. He chose to dismiss the hot inflation prints in Q1 2024 as noise until the third hot print where he basically couldnt dismiss it anymore. He acknowledged that therere seasonal factors that artificially bring up inflation early in the year and bring down inflation later in the year. If this is what he believes in, he should slowly cut until early next year and observe what inflation does, not start with 50 bps cut. Theres also the new president next year which would be inflationary no matter what, so that further adds reasons to go slow and wait until next year. Unemployment rate going up is due to more labor supply, not layoffs. Whats the rush in that? Unemployment was going up for months while we continued to add 250k jobs, and everyone was saying nothing but positive things about the economy. We only shifted down to 150k jobs for 2 months and now suddenly the labor market is weak? Consumer spending is strong, job confidence is strong. If there was any real risk of recession, economists and the market wouldve already flagged that, but none have so far. Btw, a dove focuses more on the job mandate, and a hawk focuses more on the inflation mandate. It doesnt matter what the reason for their focuses are, but Kashkari is now a much bigger dove than the rest when the rest of them saw the same data. Same with Powell.

Ive literally watched every FOMC meeting like a hawk. Shift is not something Id attribute to Powell. If anything, the story of 2024 is that he says the same thing, reiterating himself again and again and again. Hell, the whole reason the stock market would tank after each Fed meeting is because people kept expecting the dovish cuts are coming soon convo and hed stubbornly stick to hawkish dont even think about it, we need more data, promptly causing a rapid sell off in equities. The market was overpricing cuts because they literally were ignoring the words coming out of his mouth. Even as late as the June meeting, it was hawkish words To quote the above link For a seventh straight meeting, the FOMCs statement repeats language stating that the committee doesnt expect to cut rates until it has gained greater confidence that inflation is moving sustainably toward 2. Powell doubled down on the dot plots hawkish tone at the press conference, proclaiming, If the economy remains solid and inflation continues to persist, we are prepared to maintain the current rate level. If the labor market were to weaken significantly...we are prepared to respond Thats literally the exact same stance he was running for 7 meetings prior hold rates steady, wait for data. There wasnt a hint of dovishness there. He doesnt say anything like were preparing to cut soon. That didnt come until Jackson Hole following the dismal June jobs report. On the labor market, it is weak, but macroeconomics dont turn on a dime. Show me any time in history on this chart where the unemployment rate starts turning upward and then stops or declines after only three quarters of a percentage point You wont find it. Sentiment and trends are long term glacierlike snowballing effects. Its why you cant see a recession until youre in it. Because if all youre focusing on is present data whilst ignoring a clearly developing trend, youll never see it. Sure, the labor market is fine now. But thats not what Im concerned about. Do you ever wonder why the Fed is always behind the curve and seems to miss the boat all the time? Always reacting and cleaning up messes after economy implosions instead of being ahead of the ball? This is why. Theyre going to see that most recent 254k jobs report and go look, everything is fine, we can maintain the rate. Then the next month the jobs report is going to be adjusted or abysmal, and once again theyll be behind the curve. Honestly, for entities that constantly claim to care about longterm data, Im shocked at how shortterm thinking they truly are. Inflation has been on a clear downward trend since at least August 2023, and only now they start releasing the screws? When were only a half percent above 2 CPE?

your quote is not a hawkish quote. It is a neutral quote. A hawkish quote would not include the latter part where they are prepared to respond swiftly to deteriorating labor market, which is what Powell did in 2023, not mentioning any concern for the labor market. Please interpret the quote yourself instead of relying on someone else to do it for you. The FOMC statement is crafted by the WHOLE committee, not Powell alone. The dot plot was hawkish in June, but Powell was not. Powell only has control in the FOMC QA. If you think dovish signal can only come from were preparing to cut soon, youre not following the FOMC that closely. Powell can signal dovishness by what he choose to say or not say, what he chooses to emphasize. For example, therere 2 conditions for him to cut rates falling inflation, deterioration of labor market. Only 1 condition for him to HOLD rates, not even hike higher inflation. That right there shows a HUGE dovish bias, and he made this shift late last year. This is evident in the financial condition, which was the tightest late last year and have eased down to summer 2022 levels. Sp500 rallied 300 points after June FOMC. Not sure where the selloffs youre talking about are. The only time the market sold off this year due to hawkish Fed was in April after 3 consecutive bad inflation prints, but not during FOMC. Any instance when unemployment turns upwards and then stop? Summer 2023. Remember when all the recession forecasts became soft landing forecast? Or you already forgot. initial claims also spiked back then too. But why does it matter. Unemployment rate is spiking due to labor supply, not firing. Show me any instance in the past when unemployment rate spiked up due to labor supply.

That quote is only a neutral quote if were at a neutral rate. Powell himself claims the rate we were at prior to the recent half point cut was a significantly restrictive rate, with the rate were at now still restrictive even after the cut. When we get to 2 inflation, we should ideally at that point be at a neutral rate. Because of that reason, the quote is hawkish. Its ignoring the data, ignoring the trend, and preparing forassuming the worst i.e. inflation to reinflate. A neutral stance would have reacted to falling inflation by slowly reducing the rate restriction so that we would be near a neutral rate near the same time we hit 2 inflation. That is not going to happen. Were going to hit 2 CPE within months and wont be anywhere near a neutral rate until sometime in 2026 per even the latest dot plot. Unemployment didnt go anywhere in summer of 2023. That entire time unemployment was in the 3.4 3.8 range and effectively moved sideways. Mainly because we had slack from tons of job openings to absorb any declines in business activity. That buffer has all but evaporated at this point Future weakening in the job market wont come from unfilled openings, itll come from actual filled job positions. As can be seen from the upwardly trending unemployed per job opening chart I also dont know why you seem to believe that the only reason unemployment is trending up is due to supply. There are many sectors in our economy that are laying off people left and right. Tech is one of the big ones Other industries are slow to follow because companies are still afraid to release their workers after the acute shortage they just went through in the proceeding years. So they are choosing to hold workers at a loss rather than release them. At some point those fears will subside. Consumer spending has been declining through all of 2024 and people are becoming increasingly selective about where they spend their money, particularly on big ticket items. Hell, the automobile market all but collapsed people just arent buying cars anymore. Until I see any of these trends break, Im going to assume theyre going to continue. Im seeing a consumer tightening their belt more and more with every passing day, and companies downsizing more and more every passing day.

replies.text: Kind of disagree. The consumer is sick of the Starbucks ripoff. Theyre looking for value, not sweet drinks that cost as much as a meal. Id been skeptical that just tweaks could fix that. I do believe making some big and fundamental and newsgenerating changes could fix Starbucks business. I also believe the small tweaks wont do anything. Seeing that 4 point letter from Niccol screams tweaks not true fundamental change. Its as much BS corpospeak as what Laxman was putting out. Empower the barista. Please. Ive read the employeedominated sub, and the theme is theyre sick of being worked to death and it sounds like many dont even like the customers. Understand the market isnt exactly a forensic fix for China. Customers tired of being ripped off dont need to be told the Starbucks story. The name on cups gag is played out. Making Starbucks a community coffeehouse isnt really what consumers want, and isnt necessarily good for the business. They want better value and they want to get in and out quickly. The 25 pop was the market assuming Niccol could make the inandout quickly thing, and the perceived value thing happen. This letter sounds like he doesnt even understand the problem. And the market annointing him as universal problem solving saint may be misguided. Yes, CMG stock had incredible growth and the brand became widely loved... for the first half of his tenure. But the second half is not as pretty. When problems started to appear, he seemed incapable of identifying and addressing them proactively. Chipotle is now widely perceived as being a ripoff and too bland. Bad portion sizes. Skimping on ingredients and quality. He seemed paralyzed and clueless about that. His last big public appearance before abandoning the ship was him goofily claiming the portions were consistent, as big as your head, and that if you ever felt you werent getting value, you should personally try to shame the worker into topping up your plate. Thats out of touch, not problem solving. So a perhaps more sober assessment of Niccol is that he was present while CMG rode the advantage of the stock being pummeled from killing customers with unsafe food, and then when the time came to actually solve problems, he couldnt recognize them let alone solve them. And now hes the one walking into a problemfest at Starbucks. I took my 24 gains and am waiting to see what happens. If I were given that job, instead of issuing that bad, pithy letter, heres what Id do acknowledge the deep problems which are a consumer no longer willing to pay luxury price for sugary milkshakes, employees placed in unfulfilling situations, operational inability to have quick, high volume output. fixes would be in the form of Big Bang changes and candid humility. Look to the dominos model where they apologized and acknowledged cardboard level pizza. Fix the bad, burnt coffee taste perception. look also to McDonalds who knows you have to keep volume going even when consumers are strapped and sick of you, and they do that with inarguably value through literal value menus. Id have some newsgenerating low priced options as a form of Starbucks value menu look also to McDonalds who figured out how to massively pump out drive through where your order is prepared in the time it takes between ordering and paying and pickup window, and then making that parallel with two or more lanes. Id overhaul the operations substantially. Despite what coffeehouse baristas think, efficient machines can make most of a drink just fine. Weve all had delicious mass produced smoothies, Nespressos, etc. Id lean heavy on such automation and preparation to massively ramp up how much and how quickly a location can pump out the drinks, and let the baristas be more of a presentation element. Let them use their time and personalities with the customers instead of tamping away and washing seives in the back. Yes, Id be fine with a scenario where premade or machine made drinks are pumped out under a counter and a charming baritas focus on pretending they made it and making the customer feel happy and that theyve been served quickly. Make it globally known that the long lineups are over and that you can get a plain coffee for 3 from the value menu. this would address both the biggest consumer deterrents plus make life liveable for the baristas. it turns Starbucks back into a perceived affordable treat, an attainable piece of luxury at a good price. Theres more, but you get the point. Sure, theres a halo on Niccol, and a whole ecosystem of Wall Street and financial news media that is invested in claiming Starbucks is great regardless of the truth. But in terms of actual transformational change, my plan seems to have more substance than tell the Starbucks story

Ill go back to Starbucks if they drop prices by 50 and put tables back in their shops. I havent been in years because its overpriced and not even good coffee. Plus no one meets at Starbucks anymore. Its that simple.
As soon as you felt you had to explain what revenue is, I completely wrote off the rest of the post

I do this as a hobby, I like analyzing public companies. I find writing a good way to organize my analysis. The level of knowledge in this subreddit varies, so one of the goals of my posts is to make it understandable for everyone. Also, I am a fan of the quote If you cant explain it simply, you dont understand it well enough. I can use complex terms as I have the knowledge, but Ill argue that will add less value overall. Id appreciate your feedback if you read the entire post, and let me know if you disagree with it.

I worked for a major competitor for 6 years, most of which as a branch manager, and the issue Hertz has is a result of poor loss managementleadership. The amount of effort and strict protocol we had to follow to report a car stolen was significant. Following which there was an operational process to maintain, that was fully integrated in our normal day to day functions. Ifwhen we recovered a stolen car, assuming it wasnt just sold at auction, we had to take additional steps before the system let us rent the car again. No system was perfect and mistakes were made but I only ever heard about it happening once anywhere in our group. This wouldve been across millions of rental contracts. TLDR Hertz is a mess and this is entirely selfinflicted.

ubamadesi Im not sure where youre trying to go with your comment, but Ill just say the following 1. If by bio business you mean biotechs as a whole, well nobody is ever going to be familiar with all of them, and each biotech has its own idiosyncracies and unique selling points. Therefore, we ALL need to read about bio business. Also, as far as getting familiar is concerned, asking questions here is actually part of getting familiar with the sector and learning more about it. Nobody has a monopoly on knowledge. 2 Big Pharma and biotechs are not the same thing. A financial win for a Biotech company may barely move the financial needle for a Big Pharma company thats worth multiples of billions, depending on the amount of sales of the drug. If a biotechs drug is not the only drug on the market for a given illness, the money made from that drugs market share will be limited, since the Total Addressable Market will be shared with the competing drugs. There are also drugs that most of the public who need them will never see, due to the unfortunate fact that those drugs are too expensive to be massproduced for the wider market. 3 A companys revenue is very different from its stock price action. Even when a drug is sold to the public, it isnt guaranteed to translate to significant stock price increase. If a biotechs stock price doesnt move much, then that biotech isnt attractive to private investors, even if it remains desirable for a big pharma company to invest in it.

A steady trend of labor market degradation in the United States There is little doubt where this is all headed. A year ago at this time of year, the threemonth average of nonfarm job creation was at 211k, and now its only 116k 142k in August, and the longterm norm is about 190k per month. At the same time, the data for June and July were revised sharply downward by 30 or minus 86k from 293k total for the two months to 207k employed. Its still better to count in percentages, as as the economy and population grows, you need more and more employment growth in absolute terms to have a commensurate effect. The 3month average is 0.07 per month, the YTD average is 0.11, and the 12month average is 0.12, while the mediumterm rate before COVID 20172019 was 0.13 per month and the 10year longterm rate is 0.16. The visible deterioration started in June and the data is about half as bad as the longterm trend in job creation. Its not a crisis requires at least three months of job contraction or a recession a rate of about 0.03 per month averaged over 36 months, but the first clear signal. It should be taken into account that BLS manipulates data and recently lost over 800 thousand employed, yesterday they revised the data for the worse by 30 and it is not excluded that soon we will find out that all this is a complete fake and the economy is in recession since spring 2024. Real talk though, there is an abundance of evidence that timing the market leads to underperformance long term. If one is a special snowflake that thinks they are the chosen few that can outperform by active trading, good luck. Its something like 1 of active traders that consistently outperform the market. I for one accept that I dont have an edge and will utilize the optimal approach that the abundance of data supports. In the end ones savings rate and degree of career success is probably the biggest factor anyways so long as they are not blowing up their account with horrible trades.

Know when to sell is only half way. You also need go know when to buy back in. Most people waited way too long thinking they can get a lower price and ended up buying back only at a 10 discount from the price they sold. However, they now have to pay taxes on years of profit.

I think timing the market on large, expected dips, is possible, and its something that both our largest institutions and own government does. I agree that most people do not have the expertise or discretion of a professional trader whos job it is to do that, and its not a good idea for retail traders to do it, but if you use broker managed account, its probably part of their risk management to sell off stocks during uncertain times. Measuring how much traders outperform the market, to make a point on sensible risk management, isnt a good comparison. Most retail trading on the market, is no different than playing poker or sports betting. 90 of traders dont know what an edge even is, and they are timing the market the way someone predicts a roulette table. Wheras, analyzing the real economic conditions that influence the market is not just guessing and is not always a wrong bet. Unless you are willing to dedicate a lot of time and potentially some losses to learning to do this efficiently, you are better off investing the way you are told.
Yes, this is an entire science, and applies to much more than stocks

So you dont use the average. You extract what it actually is, which is the frequency of red Sept months dwarfs green Sept months to the point of skewing down the average to negative Is that so difficult to comprehend? Lol, that is still an average. Im a statistician, so no, thats not hard to comprehend. You dont have to be a douchebag. The probability of a red September is barely above 50. Its trivial. you also inferred that the other guy was talking about how trivial the return is. No I didnt, that is literally what the numbers in the comment are about. Youre the only one who made an assumption, namably, that they were trying to imply were done already, which is absurd. Of course a big daily move is gonna dwarf the average return for the whole month. Yeah, so its a good fucking point to keep in mind whether the months average is slightly positive or slightly negative lol. You accidentally arrived at the point that the OP was trying to make in this comment chain.

The frequency alone is not the same as average. Average includes both frequency and magnitude. Shouldnt a statistician know this? The probability of red Sept is about 56, and its actually the only month with red above 50, and the only month with negative average. And if you look at previous pullbackcorrection from peak to trough instead of just first days of the month as your timeline, those corrections typically all occurred around Sept or Oct. Also, the other guy didnt make any comments at all. You are the one who attached the word trivial difference to the data. So you also inferred what he meant.

The frequency alone is not the same as average. Average isnt really a hard statistical term, its a colloquialism, and generically applies to any situation where you are dividing a set of data by the size of the sample I.e., if you split months by a binary such as positivenegative return, and divide by the number of months, thats an average the frequency would just be a raw number, like 13, the average would be 56. The probability of red Sept is about 56 ... right, barely above 50. I dont even know what were talking about at this point. Who cares youd need a subgroup analysis to make this predictively meaningful anyways.

Werent GDP and wages also growing at about the same rate in 2007 as they are now? 2007 Leading up to the Great Recession, the U.S. economy saw moderate growth. In 2007, GDP growth was about 1.9 according to the Bureau of Economic Analysis BEA. Recent Years 2023 GDP growth has varied in recent years due to the impact of the COVID19 pandemic and subsequent recovery. For example, in 2021, GDP grew by about 5.7, driven by recovery from the pandemic, but this growth rate has moderated since then, with GDP growth in 2023 estimated to be around 2 to 2.5. 2007 Wage growth was relatively stagnant before the recession. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics BLS, real wage growth was minimal, with nominal wages increasing modestly but often outpaced by inflation. GDP Growth The growth rate of GDP in 2007 was lower compared to some recent years, especially during the postpandemic recovery. However, recent growth rates are beginning to resemble the moderate growth seen in 2007 as the economy stabilizes. Wage Growth Real wage growth has been more pronounced recently due to labor market pressures, but inflation has also been higher, which complicates direct comparisons. In 2007, wage growth was weaker, with stagnant real wages being a concern leading up to the recession. Recent Years 2023 Wage growth has been more dynamic in recent years, partly due to labor shortages and inflation pressures. In 2022, nominal wages increased by about 5 on average, though real wage growth adjusted for inflation has been mixed. Some quarters saw real wage declines due to high inflation, while other periods showed modest real gains. replies.text: does shiling your own stock on reddit actually work?
Revenue this quarter or past not potential. Burning cash like mad everyday.
Big empty words
I want it to work, the whole flying car thing will eventually work, but just because it works doesnt mean its a good business.
How will they address the issues that are currently stopping helicopters from filling that niche in cities today?

I am calling you about an amazing investment opportunity that has shown enormous interest for our clients in the last few months. We believe it will become one of the biggest companies in America. Its called Archer Aviation ACHR Its a cuttingedge tech firm out of the Midwest, awaiting imminent patent approval on the next generation of electrical vertical takeoff and landing aircraft eVTOL that have both huge military and civilian applications.
Do you know how yo make a million bucks in aviation?
Big milestone with the FAA announcement in support of this movement today.

Fair question, and I totally get the skepticism. The goal here isnt to shill, but to share an analysis and highlight why some people are paying attention to this space. ACHR is a speculative play, no doubt, but its also backed by real partnerships, like their contract with the U.S. Air Force, which gives them a bit more credibility. Whether its a solid investment or not is up to each individual to decide, but having an open discussion can help everyone see the bigger picture and make informed decisions.

Fair points, and I get the concern. Right now, ACHR is definitely in the cashburning phase, similar to how Tesla was in its early days. For years, Tesla was burning through cash with very little revenue, but they were laying the groundwork for the futureand it paid off in a big way. For ACHR, its about investing in RD, securing partnerships like with the U.S. Air Force, and building out the tech so that when the market is ready, theyre in a prime position. Its definitely high risk, but thats also where the potential reward comes in. Longterm plays like this can be tough, but sometimes they turn out to be gamechangers.

I get itcool tech doesnt always mean a profitable business. The key for ACHR will be scaling it and making it accessible, not just a niche product. Their partnerships with the U.S. Air Force and Stellantis help add credibility and could smooth the path to commercialization. Still risky, but the potential is there if they can get it right.

Good question. The key difference is that eVTOLs are designed to be quieter, cheaper, and more efficient than traditional helicopters. Noise is a big reason why helicopters arent widely used in cities, and eVTOLs address that with multiple smaller, quieter electric rotors. Plus, the maintenance and operating costs for eVTOLs are projected to be lower, thanks to simpler electric systems compared to gaspowered helicopters. Theyre starting with controlled routes like airport shuttles to gradually build infrastructure and public acceptance. It wont be an overnight shift, but these features are what could make eVTOLs viable where helicopters havent been.
Right now, this stock trades at a mere 3 a share, and our analysts indicate it could go a heck of a lot higher than that. Your profits on a mere 6,000 investment would be upwards of 60,000!!

Haha, I appreciate the enthusiasm, but Im not here to pitch anyone on a sure thing. ACHR is an earlystage company with real potential, but also real risks. Theyve been building partnerships like their contract with the U.S. Air Force and investing heavily in RD for eVTOL tech. Its not guaranteed to become the next big thing, but for those who see the potential in urban air mobility, its worth keeping an eye on.
Start with a billion dollars.

Unlike many software business models where scale yields better unit economics, hardware unit economics never get as good with scale. Even with the most amazing manufacturing and lean operations there is still a marginal cost of increasing scale at any point, it never results in the next to no marginal cost to scale that is achieved by SW companies. Also Stellantis is not doing too hot right now. I wouldnt use their name to increase my belief in odds of success here. Military, totally different story. The customer willingness to pay and tolerance for issues is much better. But I dont get the benefit of an eVTOL compared to any other aircraft that they have at their disposal. Sustainability is far down on the list for the military.

I would also add that evtols are safer than helicopters by design with all of the redundancies built in by the separate batteries and multiple rotorspropellers. Midnight can also operate as a fixedwing craft, taking off and landing just like airplanes already do. I think this is where the true selling point is.

How will they address the issue of throughput? The claim of a 1.5T market sounds nice but right now the top 4 helicopter manufacturers are grossing 15b in revenue, so to reach 1.5T you would have to significantly expand the market, and right now there really isnt the infra to support it.

Great points on the differences between hardware and software scaling. Its true that hardware doesnt hit the same kind of margin efficiencies, but theres still room for improvement, especially with manufacturing partnerships. Stellantis brings production expertise to the table, which could help streamline costs even if their own situation isnt perfect right now. On the military side, eVTOLs arent just about sustainabilitythey offer unique advantages like vertical takeoff and easier deployment in tight spaces, plus potentially lower maintenance. That versatility is why the U.S. Air Force is interested. The economics wont be as smooth as software, but theres a clear strategy behind why theyre targeting these areas.

Thats where eVTOLs can really open up new possibilities. Unlike helicopters, theyre designed to be quieter, cheaper, and more accessible, which can create new demand beyond niche routes. Its not just about replacing whats already there its about building a whole new way of moving around cities. The plan is to start with targeted routeslike airport transfers and short urban commutesand set up dedicated landing pads to handle the traffic. Once thats in place, theres room to scale up. Its a longterm vision, but if they pull it off, it could completely change how we think about urban mobility.

V22 provides VTOL today. Charging infrastructure is a major hurdle for the military. They want to be able to fuel an aircraft in minutes from any airport in the world. There are so many bets that need to work out that the combined probability of success is so low develop a performant aircraft, produce at scale, aircraft is better than what exists on the market today in terms of speed range maintenance, develop and deploy charging infrastructure at every airport in the world, operational capacity is limited by public air traffic controllers. Theres a lot that needs to go right. All of these things eventually went right for commercial aviation but it took 5 decades, lots of deaths which are not as tolerated today as used to be the case, government subsidies, bankruptcies, and they did not have an entrenched air transportation industry to compete with that is demonstrated to be safe and profitable at times. Edit evtol vtol for V22

Youre absolutely rightthere are huge challenges ahead, and the comparison to the V22 shows why its not just about having vertical takeoff. For eVTOLs to succeed, a lot has to go right from aircraft performance and scaling production to infrastructure and air traffic management. But thats also why the early focus is more nichelike shorter, controlled routesrather than competing headon with existing longrange aircraft. The military interest isnt just about replacing current aircraft but adding new flexibility, like silent, quick deployments in areas where larger VTOLs might struggle. As for the infrastructure, its a major hurdle, no doubt, but those are exactly the problems the industry is trying to solve stepbystep, starting with key locations rather than going global all at once. Its a highrisk, highreward scenario, and it wont be easy, but thats why it has so much potential to disrupt.
Are you using A.I. to write these responses by any chance?
No I do it on my own. I used it for spellcheck, because I am not native speaker.

replies.text: Your idea isnt going to work. First of all, just as a general rule, any consistent alpha that you can get via algorithm is probably going to get picked up by the big boys in the market and thus bid out of existence long before you can take advantage. Secondly, you plan to use TA to get an entry point, but TA is basically not a thing, not for currency or for most tradable entities. Thirdly, your plan is to use national statistics, but almost every country is going to collect this data in different ways, with different lag times, and different meanings, and with lots of room for local bias. You can use them for simple comparisons but as inputs to a sophisticated algorithm youre going to bump against their inconsistency a lot.

replies.text: Id just run the 529 up to about 100K and then start thinking about other ways to depart from it. I would not use a UTMA or UGMA rather just open another brokerage account under your name and add any money you want. Reason being, if children become heroin addicts for some reason, you do not want thousands of dollars going to their them to feed their addiction with you having no say of it. If you have a brokerage account under your name you can give to them as you see fit.

Imo, 529 and your own brokerage account are the best option. UTMAUGMA accounts are terrible for your kids if you think they are going to college. They will utterly destroy financial aide eligibility since kids are expected to pay 2025 of their assets each year of school on FAFSA as their expected contribution. If the position is just held under your name, the expected contribution is far, far lower, about 5.64. Keep it in your name and gift it after they graduate. Heres the important difference between the two with regards to financial aid the FAFSA assesses independent student assets at 20 but parent assets which includes assets owned by a student who is still a dependent on a bracketed system at a maximum rate of 5.64.3 In other words, the SAI calculation assumes that 20 of the students assets will be used to pay for schooling while only 5.64 of a parents assets will.
UTMA

What kind of account is a custodial brokerage account? I have those set up under my schwab account for my kids. Theres never been any realized gains on them so Im not sure how bad that would mess up our taxes but so far, theyve been easy to manage.

IULs are a solid option as a defensive investment strategy. Doesnt count as an asset since its tied to insurance so it wont be counted against them for financial aid. These plans are super flexible and can be used for anything, not just education. They can use towards their first car or let the cash accumulation grow for a house down payment. Includes great living benefits in case of terminal illness and will provide for long term care. If your kid lets it grow until their retirement, it can realistically reach 1M aka Million Dollar Baby Plan.

replies.text: The only thing you need to do is add some bonds and cash when you retire. This will help mitigate sequence of returns risk. Not sure what podcasters your talking about but there is no reason to make your investing more complicated.

Efficient Frontier theory is about finding the optimal balance between risk and return. Its main point is that holding uncorrelated or at least less correlated asset classes can reduce risk and increase return to a point. This is why many portfolio models consider the division of assets between US equities, international equities, and bonds. As others have commented, you definitely want to add bonds as you approach retirement. There are plenty of general guidelines and suggestions for this, but it comes down to a personal decision. Its an optimization though. VTSAX already puts you ahead of 90 of investors. Reference
If you like. Theres no right way to do an allocation.

The efficient frontier is basically position allocation to create a portfolio that maps the frontier between risk and return. So you would simulate using historical data with X number of stocks, for example, out of 1000 stocks, pick 10 and create a portfolio out of them. Repeat this Y times and it creates this frontier. Using this will give you insights into how your position allocation will expect to return.
once you make 10 million sure put it in bonds
You can leave it in vtsax but bonds or CDs will protect you it drops 40 like it does every 10 years

Holding multiple asset classes with correlation 1 increases your return per unit risk. The efficient frontier is the set of portfolios that maximize this return per unit risk. So why is it good to increase you return per unit risk when youre decreasing your overall return? Because you can use leverage. If you lever up this lower returnperunitrisk portfolio, you can replicate the same overall return at lower risk. This kind of portfolio construction becomes more useful when you have more capital because a lot of good lowbeta less correlated to the market investments have large minimum commitments and are only available to accredited investors.

replies.text: Every service or broker seems to have all drastically different numbers. Each service only knows its own volume. The volume of one exchange is not the same as that of another exchange, just as their price histories also differ. For example, the price history and volume of GBPUSD on FXCM and OANDA will differ. If youre using two different data brokers to access information about the same exchange platform, thats a different matter that should be looked into. For example, if you use both TradingView and Yahoo Finance to view info about the GBPUSD market on OANDA, you should see the same figures on both sites. If you dont, something is amiss.

One solid option for accurate intraday data is TickData. Theyre known for their detailed and reliable datasets. Another one to check out is Quandl. Just do remember that no data provider is perfect, so crossreferencing can help get the best picture.
Yahoo only does EOD, EOW, or EOM data. Not talking exchange by exchange. If you take Tastytrade, IBKR, ToS all different with different intraday volumes and the all use NCCO.

Of course its true. This is a basic tenet of tax loss harvesting. After offsetting capital gains, remaining loss can offset ordinary income up to 3000 per year, and any further remaining amounts being able to be carried forward to future tax years.

replies.text: I personally have a 529 set up for my child. IMO with recent changes and being able to transfer 35k of unused funds to a Roth IRA for them at 18 its the superior choice. By retirement age without adding any more money that 35k is 23 million. If they continue to max contributions until 65 theyre looking to retire in the 710 million range

You dont say where you live but in the US there are 3 things Ive done to help my kids. 2 of the 3 were started when they were born. 1. Started a 529 investment account for education expenses. The key benefit is tax free withdrawal. These started as college only accounts. Federal law changes have been made over the years allowing these accounts to be used for precollege education expenses, but not all states allow this. The downside of this is the money can only be used for education and related expenses. 2. Started a custodialtrust account for long term stock investment. Normal tax rules apply. The money can be used for anything. Considerations Kids are not the best at rational decision making at 18. For this reason a trust account may help you provide some oversight of the funds use. 3. A custodial account for the kids personal savings. I set this up with them to teach financial literacy. I just did this for my kids last week now that theyre both preteenteens. We discuss the benefits of investing, approaches, help them identify opportunities, and help them make the transactions. Why 3 approaches? I first set up 529 accounts because the tax benefits are great. As life went on I realized that going to college isnt the norm it used to be. My wife and I expect our kids to go to college and beyond ideally, but if they decide to go another route then I didnt want all their savings to be locked up in a 529. After discussing this with my wife we started the trust fund brokerage accounts to counter balance the 529 contributions we make. Any gift money the kids receive we throw in their trust brokerage account. Both accounts are about even at this point. Clearly the earlier you start the better. The custodial brokerage accounts I just set up are education focused. Ive read too many stories about kids being financially illiterate. If I made the effort to set them up for success I didnt want them to squander it. Education is the key so I figured getting them taking part and building their interest as teens was a smart way to go. One thing for you to factor in... Change. Be ready for it. Kids personalities and needs vary. Economic societal shifts are happening all the time. Investing is easier but also prone to be abused like social media. College used to be the way... now there are boot camps for kids to concentrate on one thing and bypass a 4 year degree. A kid may decide being a plumber is a noble profession and have no interest in college. God forbid your child may have health or education issues. Use of the money is impossible to predict and if you or your spouses expectations are locked in you might have a challenging time down the road. Food for thought.

Give them a fish they eat for a day, teach them to fish they eat forever. My education quadrupled my net worth. I worked in a factory for 12 years and was laid offrehired so many times. Went to school, quadrupled my salary in 10 years, never been laid off again, and became a 401k millionaire at 50. Money can be taken or lost, but an education is always with you.

Both. Put some into a 529 account but keep an eye on the amount over time. Make sure that amount stays reasonable, essentially dont over fund the 529. Put the rest into a long term savings brokerage account. Reasonable college fund amounts vary. My goal is about 75 of tuition, room, and board at a state school. The rest my daughter will be responsible for. This means she has personal financial investment into her education and there is room for merit based scholarships. It also isnt an amount so large that its prohibitive to gift it to her later on say, when she graduates and gets her first job. Also fully fund your retirement first. Anything you put into a custodial account will be fully accessible to your child between 1821. Adults at those ages have significant challenges with impulse control and have a none zero chance of spending it all before they are 25. You will probably be able to better support your childs financial freedom if you have ensured your own first and then help them with lifes biggest financial challenges as they mature. Help them buy their first car, pay most but not all of their college tuition, help them with their first down payment on a house. But Im not sure handing a 1821 year old the proceeds of a brokerage account is a good idea.

You can do both, that what Im doing. With society business reducing the need for college as a requirement to work, you want to make sure you dont overfund the account. The federal government has allowed up to 35k of a 529 to be rolled over into an IRA. We also have an UTMA for both kids. In that account we are invested in VOO 60 DGRO 20 SOXQ 15 VXUS 5. We contribute 100mo that is split between the 529 UTMA. All BDay Xmas money goes into the account.
Youre assuming your kid, at 18, will be mature enough to handle their investments. Ill bet by 26 that money is gone. That of course if papa doesnt screw it all up...already on Reddit though.

I chose option 2 for my kids for maximum flexibility and the miscalculation I made is that if they choose to go to college and need to sell to pay for tuition they will owe taxes at my marginal rate if they are still dependents. Fortunately, weve managed to work around it that they dont need to sell thanks to some other arrangements, but I felt pretty silly for not planning for that.

Investment account for them, teacher your child financial literacy, college will likely be replaced by something better and cheaper. Right now college takes about 4 of life expectancy time and costs a lot. College kids paying to be someone bottom B. They should be paid to go to college. But thats just my opinion.

Eek, not a fan of stop losses. Its pretty well known that HFT scalps them. They have the ability to find your stops using deep book analytics and, if the situation presents itself, theyll knock you out. Youre better off entering positions with options and then continue to use them to hedge. For example, buy a 12 month LEAP on whatever youre interested in, if it moves in your way, sell a shorter expiry against it. You can usually get whatever premium you paid for the option back using this method, still book gains, and have a built in stop loss by using the option.

So heres the problem I was working on today. I had a table of values that I needed to add an effective date to. Im looking at the UI, which just lists the values in a grid, and thinking after I add the effective date to the grid how do I allow the user to add a new line with values where they can just change the effective date and one or two of the values on the line. Finally decided I would get a pic of a calendar, shrink it down to an icon, stick that on the end of the grid next to the icon that adds a blank line, so that when they click on the calendar it copies that line and adds it to the end of the grid, then I decided Id fill in the effective date with todays date, put the focus on that, so that theyd get a line with all the values copied and be able to change the effective date first, and then go and edit the rest of the values as needed. So an AI is going to be told to add an effective date and heres the UI. Figure it out. Somehow I dont see it coming up with a userfriendly solution. It would actually have to be a human with eyes and fingers to know to design the UI so that at a glance the user will know what to do. I could give the AI the task of writing the code to copy the line after the icon is pressed, but thats a trivial thing that takes me a minute to write. Its the figuring out how to present it to the user in a fashion they can understand that takes the time.

LLMs rely on text and visual data. Most of this is scraped from the internet. Higherquality, curated data results in higher quality output. Much like in traditional search results, data coming from sources like Wikipedia, major news outlets, scientific papers and think tanks is likely to yield more accurate and useful results. AI companies know this and they assign greater weight to the tokenized text from highquality sources. As LLMs get larger, they are more likely to scrape outdatedirrelevant data from places like arguments on old gaming forums, Reddit satire, or PornHub comments. The more bad data they include, the more likelihood of hallucinations incomplete or incorrect data. The same methodology applies to code found online. Sites like W3 Schools, Stack Overflow, MSDN, Google opensource, SourceForge and highlystarred entries from GitHub are very useful, but these are already incorporated into most LLMs. Adding older and less well moderated code wont improve things much, and may actually make the results worse. Hackers might even post malicious code snippets to trick LLMs into suggesting them to users. Quality of data isnt the only improvement that AI companies could make, however. They could tweak their algorithms to detect obvious bugs or hacks prior to delivering them, for example. They also might be able to detect when a given code block obviously wont compile or is referencing a library that has been replaced. These are tweaks, however. It is still garbage ingarbage out. In the long term, AI will likely win out. A system that is always getting better will eventually overtake a system that is static the human brain. The question is, how long? I personally believe that it will take something more than chatbots to displace senior programmers.

Im not that guy, but Im a software engineer that uses AI every day as part of my work. No longer work for a FAANG company, but its still at the same level. LLMs are great for a lot of stuff. Its pretty good at generating trivial code in less time than it would take to write it, especially if youd need to spend a couple minutes reading documentation to learn how to do it. But things rapidly break down when given complex or open ended instructions. It also makes lots of really dumb errors. Having it to discovery and design work? Holy crap thats so far outside its capabilities I dont even know where to start. If AI can do what you do at your job, that says more about what you do than what AI can do. AI cannot do what I do, and it isnt close. Ive tried. Ive put lots of effort into trying to make this work. And it can only do the most trivial tasks, like making a reddit scraper or creating permutations of a unit test, or generating documentation boilerplate for you to then manually edit. And thats really the key here, is that even in the best case, what AI produces is still below my standards and I have to manually edit it. And then theres the problem of it only being good at the languages that have lots and lots of examples to scrape. Python and Java? Fine. C? A little less so. Your companys proprietary SQL variant with unique grammar? Lol no, not even after you give it the documentation. AI is a replacement for people who dont know what theyre doing. It is not a replacement for professionals.

Better prompts can get you closer, but someone with no coding experience would likely hit a brick wall at this point.

Let me help everyone here. AI isnt the concern. LLMs only want to talk to you somehow. Theyre generative conversational AIs. Machine learning, which is a segment of the AI space, is absolutely concerning. This is field data study. Its the idea that I can take all the decisions you guys have made over the last decade in a piece of software and apply a machine learning algo to that field of data so I then can make assumptions based on what actual humans did. This is how we get an LLM, but its also how we automate a dock or Fiverr. We have to teach the machine to replace the human, but make no mistake.. machine learning is a drive forward in the realm of replacing humans with machines. Machine learning in industrial and commercial settings is a concern for every worker on earth, whether you understand it or not, because they are already replacing humans with these machines and were just getting started. Regardless of if you think itll work or not, they do think itll work, and they will still till they know it wont. And since the tech grows while they implement it, its highly likely that it will fill a ton of needs humans filled traditionally. Another important caveat is that Nvidia has produced chipsets that can handle massive ML implementations. That chipset is the size of a desktop computer now smaller even. Weve had ML for a long time now, we just never had an affordable parser you could slap into any office on earth. As we speak, I am capable of replacing all of my regular dd friends with machine learning. Microsoft offers tech that allows me to capture their mannerisms and speech within moments of hearing their voice. OpenAi and others offer tools to parse the collected data, building my own AI from the recorded dd sessions. A year or two at work here and I could legitimately play dd with all my buddies without any of them being there and it would be very much like they were actually there. Perfect? No. But it doesnt need to be to get shit done. i learned all this tech from here I wanted to build a listener that took all the daily standups in wallstreetbets back when we had them here on Reddit and then parsed all the audio down into possible plays.. like an hour of conversation would be like 30 tickers and sectors and etc, with some collective sentiment for each. I wanted to capture all this and boil it down to ticker sentiment. In that endeavor, I found Microsofts offering I refered to above as well as most of the stuff Im talking about here. Had to know what options I had to really do the thing. I never finished this project, but wsb effectively taught me all this. Small world. Its important to understand that simulating the DM in that circumstance is far harder than simulating the players. Im also capable of creating a digital infinite storybook. For every new page you turn, you will see new art and new story relative to the story as it has been told thus far, but this new page didnt exist until the moment you turned to it.. and I can generate infinite new pages. This is a literal infinite storybook. We can make this today and it will be really fkn cool. Youre welcome for the idea if you steal it. Throw me 1m for every 10 you make and well call it even. This is wsb. I will sue you if you build this because this comment is timestamped. Also, consider this. Even if the ML implemention messed up 5 of the time, thats still within the margin of error for human operation, so its acceptable that it isnt perfect. Plus, if the machine fucks up 5, it doesnt lose an arm in those instances and workers comp never happens.

Sorry, but parrot LLM camp will be on the wrong side of history. Its pathetic how some are clinging to the notion that just because youre training on next token predicting, that you end up with a statistical parrot. Youre also confusing the training objective with what the model does in the end. An important second step to get anything resembling a coding assistant is RLHF DPO, otherwise youd just have an auto complete language model. A really beautiful proof of emergent abilities is chess LLM Every game you play in chess ends up being unique more games of chess possible than there are atoms in the fucking universe. In other words, the LLM model cant just bullshit its way through by parroting something it had seen before. It has to learn the rules of the game and actually play the game correctly to get an ELO of 1500. Anything else, coding, translating, etc emerges similarly. The model has to learn the rules of the game, in order to do it really well. Our brains work similarly remixing stuff we have seen before to come up with new solutions. That doesnt mean we are parrots. We too learn the rules of the game.

The DD is indeed bending reality. In addition to Vogtle 34, there was another project that survived the postFukushima wipeout of US new nuclear builds. That was V C Summer 23, another pair of AP1000s. Westinghouse was so far behind schedule and over budget in building these four plants that it went bankrupt. Thats why a private equity firm like Brookfield owns them in the first place before it sold half to Comeco. The V C Summer utility decided not to continue, but the Vogtle utility did, at great cost. Its because of this experience and the fact that wind and especially solar are far cheaper these days that no one is looking to build more AP1000s, or any other large nuclear reactors, in the US. Europe has had similar experiences in France, Finland, and the UK. Among nonauthoritarian countries in the last couple of decades, only South Korea has managed to build large nuclear reactors on a reasonable budget and schedule. Id be very wary of all the hype around nuclear, be it uranium, SMRs, or large reactors.

I think we can safely classify China as authoritarian. The UAE too. Haiyang and Sanmen are AP1000s, which, fwiw, is a really great design with excellent safety features. But yes, theyre building a bunch of clones on their own because Westinghouse gave them the IP.

Oh, the AP1000 is a great design, as youll see downthread on the other reply to my comment. Definitely the best LWR design currently on the market. But the nuclear industry always claims that theyll learn their lessons and the next build will be smoother and on time and budget. And it never is. Basically every plant built in the 70s and 80s in the US had huge overruns, and many were cancelled after TMI. Even Watts Bar took much longer to complete than expected. Flamanville in France and Olkiluoto in Finland were similar. Frances original build out in the 70s was similarly over. Taiwan ended up cancelling the ABWRs in Longmen, and that was after a dozen or so were built in Japan. Unless youre an authoritarian country, or maybe South Korea, youre very likely to take far more money and time to build every large nuclear reactor. This time wont be different. This is unfortunately why the nuclear industry, which should be a perfect complement to solar and wind, and perfect for AI, is instead a sunset industry.

TLDR Early March 2020 Hesitated to invest in masks due to market chaos. A trusted supplier offered KN95 masks, leading to first order of 250,000 masks. Market was chaotic stories of buyers offering cash directly at factories. First order sold quickly, yielding 172,600 in profit. Second shipment 1 million masks sold, earning 1.57 million in profit. Third shipment 1.06 million masks and 20,000 gowns sold, adding 1.08 million in profit. Total profit from first three shipments 2.83 million. Fourth shipment 5.15 million masks planned, costing 11.12 million. U.S. government regulation and market collapse caused 5 million loss, wiping out previous profits. Overall, despite 13.87 million in total sales, ended with significant losses.
