For all the regards who need a geography lesson The Gulf of Mexico is a basin to and a sea of the Atlantic Ocean. A sea is a region of the ocean partly surrounded by land. A basin is a depression in the land that water flows into. The Gulf of Mexico is a depression that the Atlantic Ocean flows into.

I used an expensive ChatGPT preview credit and got this reply Historically, when a major hurricane hits Florida, certain types of stocks tend to experience a surge due to increased demand for their products and services during the recovery and rebuilding phases. Below are the types of stocks that have historically gone up following significant hurricanes in Florida, supported by data and examples. 1. Home Improvement Retailers Companies Home Depot HD, Lowes Companies LOW Example After Hurricane Irma in September 2017, both Home Depot and Lowes saw a significant increase in sales. According to their quarterly reports, Home Depots samestore sales rose by 7.9, and Lowes saw a 5.7 increase, attributed largely to hurricanerelated purchases. Reason Hurricanes cause extensive property damage, leading homeowners and contractors to purchase building materials, tools, and supplies for repairs and rebuilding. 2. Construction and Building Materials Suppliers Companies Vulcan Materials Company VMC, Martin Marietta Materials MLM Example PostHurricane Michael in October 2018, Vulcan Materials reported a 15 increase in shipments to Florida in the following quarter. Reason The demand for construction aggregates like crushed stone, sand, and gravel spikes as rebuilding efforts commence. 3. Generator Manufacturers Companies Generac Holdings Inc. GNRC Example After Hurricane Irma, Generacs stock price increased by over 20 within a month. The company reported a surge in sales of portable and home standby generators. Reason Power outages lead to increased purchases of generators for both residential and commercial use. 4. Waste Management and Debris Removal Companies Waste Management Inc. WM, Clean Harbors Inc. CLH Example Following Hurricane Andrew in 1992, Waste Management secured numerous contracts for debris removal, boosting their revenues in the subsequent quarters. Reason Hurricanes generate vast amounts of debris that require prompt and extensive cleanup efforts. 5. Construction Equipment Rental Companies Companies United Rentals Inc. URI, HE Equipment Services HEES Example In the aftermath of Hurricane Wilma in 2005, United Rentals saw a notable uptick in equipment rentals in Florida, as per their annual report. Reason Contractors need additional equipment to handle the increased workload during rebuilding phases. 6. Roofing and Building Product Manufacturers Companies Owens Corning OC, Beacon Roofing Supply Inc. BECN Example Owens Corning reported a 12 increase in roofing material sales after Hurricane Irma, according to their 2017 annual report. Reason Roof damage is one of the most common issues after a hurricane, leading to higher demand for roofing materials. 7. Lumber and Wood Product Companies Companies Weyerhaeuser Company WY, LouisianaPacific Corporation LPX Example PostHurricane Katrina in 2005 while not in Florida, the trend is similar, lumber prices spiked, benefiting companies like Weyerhaeuser. Reason Rebuilding efforts require large quantities of lumber, driving up demand and prices. 8. Homebuilders Specializing in Renovations Companies Masco Corporation MAS, PulteGroup Inc. PHM Example Masco Corporation saw increased orders for cabinetry and plumbing products after hurricanes due to home renovations. Reason Homeowners often take the opportunity to upgrade or remodel damaged homes during repairs. Data and Reports Supporting These Trends Federal Emergency Management Agency FEMA Reports Indicate billions of dollars are allocated for rebuilding, which funnels into these sectors. National Association of Home Builders NAHB Notes spikes in construction activity posthurricanes. Stock Performance Analysis Historical stock data shows upward trends for these companies in the months following major hurricanes. Considerations Insurance Companies While it might seem they would suffer due to payouts, sometimes insurance stocks stabilize or even rise if the impact is less severe than anticipated or if they have substantial reinsurance coverage. ShortTerm vs. LongTerm Gains The immediate aftermath sees the most significant stock movements. Investors often anticipate these trends and may invest accordingly before the hurricane makes landfall. Overall Economic Impact While certain sectors benefit, the overall economic impact of hurricanes can be negative due to disruptions in tourism, agriculture, and other industries vital to Floridas economy. Conclusion Stocks in home improvement, construction materials, equipment rentals, and related sectors have historically risen following major hurricanes in Florida. The increased demand for rebuilding and repair services drives this trend. Investors looking at historical data can observe these patterns and may consider them when making investment decisions posthurricane events.

Because when there is an event that causes a massive disruption in oil prices the price of oil rises and you can earn twice the money. But leveraged etfs naturally decay over time because of math so you dont want to leave it in forever.
You trade in and out dumbass look at the trends

If the underlying moves 10 a 2x leveraged would move 20. Its good for short term trades. In order to maintain that peg, and also not go broke if the underlying goes 50 over any period of time, they need to reallocate daily. This means that gains and losses are compounding. At a certain multiple, compounding losses will always override compounding gains. For example, if you gain 40, then lose 30, youre at about breakeven. If you gain 80 then lose 60, youre almost at a 30 loss.
leveraged ETFs are for daytrading. anyone who holds overnight either doesnt know what theyre doing or is doing so for a very specific reason.

you only buy it for trends, the reason they generally sink is volatility decay and daily resets which kills the value of LETFs over time, thats why they are terrible investments and good trading tools short investment horizons

Second the people paying mortgages on unlivable homes after a storm are usually just waiting for their insurance to pay out, unless their bank didnt require flood insurance because they lived in a low risk area, in which case theyre truly boned. Always get flood insurance people! But even if their insurance eventually drops them and they cant find any other insurance the bank will still find their own and it will be expensive. It will only cover the bank getting their money back and will likely make the mortgage payments unaffordable.

Actually, if you have a mortgage and no insurance. The bank will place lender placed insurance on the property and make you pay it. Its usually more expensive than the insurance you would normally be able to get. But these banks arent stupid. They have insurance to protect themselves. Also, a lot of insurance companies have reinsurance to prevent them from going bankrupt. The case that you may get screwed if you have an insurance carrier that is nonadmitted. They have like a 10M loss cap and then they go bankrupt. Your policy will have this stated on the cover in big red letters. I had a policy like this years ago before I truly understood what it meant.

Availability set the pattern very early on in the settlement of the US. Wood was cheap, and it was everywhere being literally in the way and needing to be cut anyway. Bricks were more expensive, stone as well. Regionally you will find more brick or stone, but the pattern was set and construction continued to use timber frames because of cost and expectations. Call it a style trend, Americans like brick but consider cinder block or concrete construction to look cheap. The thought that they are inherently weak is perpetrated by the extreme storms seen here but not of the type seen in Europe. It is true that a concrete and rebar house can survive a hurricane, but unless it is built to impractical standards it could still be flooded and loose its roof. You can rebuild on the walls, maybe, but the interior is still destroyed and it needs a complete roof replacement at the least. But there is no true guarantee that even that type of construction will survive either. I saw many destroyed in the aftermath of Katrina. 15 feet of water, it hit 30 ft in some areas, will take out much more than someone can comprehend without seeing it. This may help a bit That said, you can find many 200 year old wood construction homes, but the comparative young age of the country makes them less common than in Europe.

While the history came from resource limitations and availability, Europe was clearcut when we were drowning in pristine old growth forests, the modern reason is we invented balloon framing .4 to .6 meter spaced framed homes easy to build quickly with minimal skill clad in plastic and sheetrock 10 per 3 square meters enabling the minimum possible materials to build your 15002 meter faux mansion, or incredibly cheapprofitable shitbox. Shortsighted for sure but it was never the driving concern.

They have an overall cap. National Flood Insurance Program policyholders can choose their amount of coverage. The maximum for residential structures for a family of onetofour is 250,000 in building coverage and 100,000 in contents coverage. For residential structures of five or more units, the maximum is 500,000 in building coverage and 100,000 in contents coverage.
So the thing is, the property would have been I insured by the bank if the borrower lapsed coverage. They would foreclose and rebuild. Then sell.

Kasparov thinks the issue is a tendency to presume that everyone else shares your innate world view. The key here is western ideas of motive and rationality. Western culture is soaked in a capitalist ethos, underpinned by a widespread assumption that the profit motive rules supreme in terms of shaping political calculations, and that its the economy, stupid that drives decisionmaking in Russia and elsewhere. The collapse of the USSR reinforced this view, since it seemed that market principles and global business interests had triumphed. As a consequence, western leaders and business groups generally turned a blind eye when Putin gave speeches that clearly demonstrated his nationalist, expansionist agenda and then annexed Crimea. Worse, they failed to appreciate how isolated Putin had become. Instead, as Russian oligarchs became a fixture of global business, Putin was seen as an extrapolation of this group. The idea that he might be so hellbent on the destruction of democracy and the expansion of Russia that he would be willing to accept deep economic pain wasnt taken seriously. Okay full reply. Seems like you have some level of both emotional investment in this and a fairly specific viewpoint, likely from an engineering perspective. That or you just read the grizzly report and believed it I dunno. Bad Product...1000lbs heavier than Joby Its true midnight is heavier, but Id need more information to understand why this would strictly rule out competition with Joby. The Midnight airframe is very specifically targeted at slightly shorter operational routes and urban air taxi service compared to Jobys design. Additional weight could be for stability, passenger features, or the use of cheaper OEM parts instead of custom design. They have not demonstrated full flight. the video here pretty conclusively demonstrates a full size Midnight airframe flying. I would like more information about, specifically, the Flight Data Im aware Joby published data about noise in conjunction with NASA, but Im not sure if thats specifically what youre referencing here? Additionally, USAF took delivery of a functional full size Midnight airframe I am assuming that they would not take on a full size vaporware. Founders are business leaders vs technocrats Gonna be honest here, my entire OP is about why this isnt a bad thing, more on this in the next point. using too many vendors and integrating them is a huge problem. This is how the entire aerospace industry works, not a huge problem. Archer is able to source from so many companies because those companies exist as suppliers to aerospace companies already. this article covers the divergent strategies between ACHR and JOBY in depth Of note But when it comes to their specific manufacturing strategies, the two companies have staked out sharply different paths Joby is vertically integrated and largely develops its components and systems inhouse, while Archer is pursuing a more traditional model by relying on a roster of Tier 1 legacy aerospace suppliers. The article goes on to quote Adam Goldstein specifically saying that they are aware that an IKEA aircraft as you call it is an 80 solution but provides a significantly superior market entry point. Uber Elevates engineer is even quoted as speculating that Joby will eventually divest from its full vertical integration. nbsp Again, this point and both ACHRs quotes and the note that no aerospace company comes close to the level of vertical integration Joby is pursuing is exactly what my post is about ACHRs path to revenue is WAY more clean than Jobys Stellantis investment is all shares I cover this in my OP. ACHR has far fewer outstanding shares than Joby even after considering a 400m issuance to Stellantis through 2030. Their plant is going to stay idle for a long time Why? Even if theyre not fully certified when the plant becomes operational, ramping up will take time and they have a global orderbook including shipping to international customers which may have different certification timelines or requirements. Keep issuing more ESOPs and founder has left Admittedly, I dont know how significant potential dilution from this is, but usually, ESOPs arent so massive as to completely shift the dynamic of investing outcomes. most of my options are closer in with lower price target adjustment, yes. the 2026 ones just came out pretty recently. Yeah since you didnt read I guess you missed that part. Jobys market cap is about 3.7bn. Of that, almost 1bn is cashshort term assets. ACHRs cap is about 1.26bn, of which about 450m is cashshort term assets. This leaves about 2.7bn and .8bn in speculative, long term, and IP patent, tech value respectively. nbsp Joby has fully acquired i.e. owns the IP H2Fly Hydrogen powertrain, Xwing autonomous flight, and Uber Elevate ElevateOS for ride ordering. Moreover, Joby has customdesigned nearly their entire airframe. When combined with speculative valuation from successfully entering operations, this value seems fairly reasonable. Even in a bear case, Joby potentially has multiple outlets to offer itself for acquisition or pivot to another method e.g. conversion of existing planes to hydrogen and autonomous flight. nbsp Given the IP disparity Archer designs its own battery packs and some other components, along with the actual airframe of course, my thesis is that Jobys IP and slight schedule lead are now diminishing in relative value compared to Archers actual business plan. Jobys IP stack is cool, but certifying custom build, and operational scaling are going to be harder than for Archer... With certification and operations set to begin next year, Archers superior orderbook and market plans should be valued equivalently to Jobys IP lead at this time. nbsp TLDR Joby fair value for their IP stack and superior product ACHRs superior market entry plan and order book should be worth more now, as risk of complete failure diminishes and likelihood of going to market increases.

Yeah Ive seen this and the only substantive issue, especially in the year since this report was published, may be the facility monitoring, Ill get back to that piece in a bit. Overall, and ironic considering their claims of ACHR being misleading, I find the report to be pretty deliberately misleading itself. Top line, Archer has clearly built and flown at least several completely functional Midnight airframes since that report. Regarding the USAF contract Archer has since delivered a fully functional Midnight airframe to the Air Force. Its true that they are behind Joby, but thats always been the case, and I am assuming neither the FAA Special Airworthiness Cert nor the USAF would take delivery of a scam product or vaporware at least, not a full airframe. The USAF potential order for airframes is not a substantial piece of ACHRs overall order book or operating revenue plans in any case, but I dont see why they wouldnt be able to deliver on the relatively small order if USAF continues to pursue it. They mention ACHR contracts with USAF related to autonomous flight and other highertech initiatives. I do find it likely ACHR will not continue as a leader in that space, as Jobys technology in these areas is indeed superior, as I mention in my OP. These contracts are a fraction 30M or less of the main eVTOL initiative there in any case. Highlighting these as potential losses is misleading in the context of ACHRs main business. Grizzly consistently mentions the dollar value of exercised warrants and share awards in the context of the obviouslyinflated price of August 23. While yes, those shares may be worth a considerable amount if ACHR succeeds in going to market, Grizzly leads with very large numbers attached to those share issuances while barely mentioning how unusual a price above 7 is for ACHR. Also as I addressed in OP, Grizzly talks up Joby throughout, but Jobys total share dilution is over double ACHRs total outstanding shares to this day. While there may be valid complaints about dilution, its outrageous to be in up arms over the issuances when a key competitor has done so much more. They obliquely imply that the companies investing in ACHR are doing so because theyre being given an opportunity to sell out of the company at the inflated share price. Stellantis has since continued to agree to investments in the company, with direct sharesforwork programs to ramp manufacturing. This is a pretty clear rebuttal of a number of points made by Grizzly. nbsp Regarding the manufacturing, flight videos, and overall progress being clouded ACHR has ramped up PR and specific posting of facilities and progress on the Georgia plant. Midnight clearly exists and clearly flies, including a more recent 10 minute unedited flight test video, an exact rebuttal of one of Grizzlys issues Where they posted a similar uncut Joby video. Its also a little odd that Grizzly was complaining about editing to make a flight appear longer in a video that was already only 042 seconds, which... okay? The source who claimed 2028 was Optimistic for certification is clearly not tracking how overall sector is making progress. If thats the case, Joby would be on target for 2027 at best also, and they have a complete custom ecosystem to certify, not just offtheshelf parts. Both companies, in the year following, are maintaining target times and presenting percenttocompletion that still targets 2025. It is possible still that Archers certification will be delayed to late 25 or 2026... I do find it worrying that they are still a little handwavey about their completely compliant for credit airframes being ready to go or in testing. I have addressed schedule risks several times when posting about the sector and ACHR specifically. That said, since August 23, their main Georgia plant is clearly progressing and they maintain the EOY timeline for completion as of this quarter. nbsp The claims about doing on site observation of the airport are at least interesting. However, its notable that the week they spent observing was exactly when the full size Midnight was built but not yet FAA certified. This timeframe lines up with the archer engineer saying they would have to wait as I find it rather plausible flight tests were paused between completion of the Midnight full size prototype and its airworthiness certification note that the continue to test flight daily were from prior announcements that occurred before their observational period I also have very little faith in the reports of supposed eyewitnesses when they are being asked about things by a literally activist shortseller company... Maker and Midnight are both quiet and small airframes, unique looking, true, but also short range. A full test flight could occur over the space of an hour or less, so even daily test flights may be missed routinely by people simply on the same airport grounds. Note that Grizzly did not consult or reference FAA Air Traffic Control, flight plan logs, or other possible authoritative sources for air time. Moreover, the empty facility they visited is very definitely online given that actual photo and video from the manufacturing process has been posted, and, again, at least several operational midnight airframes exist including one that USAF deemed acceptable for delivery. nbsp TO BE CLEAR I am not saying ACHR is definitely a superstar company thats going to be shitting out eVTOLs into the air taxi market next year... I just dont think that the piece published by Grizzly is a reasonable analysis.

First of all, if youre holding shares, you should be fine over a longer time horizon, this is around where we should bottom out... why ACHR is valued how it is right now Archer and JOBY, and all other eVTOL companies except EHang in china, are prerevenue companies. In other words, theyre spending money on RD but havent yet begun operations. Archer isnt actually selling or flying airframes commercially yet. As a result, traditional valuations such as PE, Dividend return, DCF, and other methods are either difficult or impossible to apply as a valuation mechanic. financial information such as cash burn rate compare to likely start of revenue generation substitute for this as a risk indicator. It does have generally nonbinding commitments for airframe sales valued at 6bn, as well as plans to selfoperate an air taxi service. Along with projected growth in the new Advanced Air Mobility sector, archer is theoretically well positioned for massive growth when operations do begin... Conversely, two major risks remain to getting operations. Most notably, type certification from the FAA saying the aircraft can fly passengers, and scaling of manufacturing supply chain and completion of main assembly line. Theres also a wider risk of a lack of infrastructure to support Air Taxis or the sector simply not catching on as something the public pays for. Essentially, the value of the company is then Possible major growth as a first mover in a new industry minus risk of catastrophic failure. Investing long term is saying Im parking money here knowing im speculating on success while short selling is saying i think the risks here are too great, and this company will fail before reaching operations. Why, specifically, its current exact value? Well, per my post, i have no idea and think its undervalued, so i am invested, but other people clearly have assessed the risk profile differently. nbsp As to why its red or green on any given day... its generally red and low priced when no catalysts or news comes out... Archer is very much on the hook to be much more concrete about its schedule, and soon, or the perceived risks grow a lot... many people are probably getting scared off by the relative lack of news given the supposedly tight timeline to start production. it goes WAY green when catalysts hit... new deals, timelines being confirmed, advances in certification progress, etc... that is, when the likelihood of future revenues increase and risks decrease and investors pile in. nbsp EOY prediction... Given the above and the fact that i am heavily invested in Oct and Jan calls. whatll happen? Basically two possible routes 1. ACHR begins for credit FAA type certification flights and proceeds quickly due to having mostly off the shelf parts i cover this vs Jobys custom build in my OP, and completes its Georgia manufacturing plant. If both of these occur by EOY, we probably go back to near 52w high 7 if not higher. 2. Any delays, setbacks, or major negative news occurs, or radio silence continues, and price continues to tank as investors look for shorter term gains and are unwilling to keep money parked in ACHR while it struggles to get running. nbsp Past EOY 24 to EOY 25 If they succeed in an entry in service date by EOY 25, that is, commercial operations begin, then we get to see an ASTSlike move in the price, as retail and institutions surge in on the hype train. This may be dampened a bit if Joby enters service earlier especially if Joby begins operations and encounters problems with operations We may see pops much earlier in 25 if nonbinding order agreements become binding as a result of Certification. 6bn in confirmed order backlog would be MASSIVE compared to 6bn in uncommitted orders. Conversely, if for credit testing begins but they faildelay for some reason, price tanks back to 3 range. If manufacturing plant has delays or failures, or production stalls due to supply chain issues, commensurate reduction in share price. nbsp Overall if you have shares you have several strategies Very long hold, as the Bull case through 2030 implies explosive potential 10x or more in share price, more if we get meme price spikes Sell on hype taking profits next time really good news comes out... then either be happy with that or rebuy when price slips between good news announcements. nbsp why do i have shorter term options? Well i have shares too, the short term options I play are very much gambling... but, as i describe above, this very speculative tech sector can see impressively insane hype spikes. Great news about beginning for credit testing or new orders or firm commitments, all trigger runs past 5 to 67. The time between now and EOY 24 is absolutely critical for the stated timeline and therefore speculative options could pay out massively. If price spikes, i also take out Strangles add puts to the mix to account for bad news and price drops.

SpaceMobile is seen as the competitor to Elons Starlink. But investors are clamoring over ASTS claiming it has no rivals and dominates the space. No, it is targeting the D2C market, which Starlink and TMobile only began targeting AFTER they realized AST was indeed going to succeed in launching their test satellite. The timing and nature of the announcement were telling. So rather, Starlink is attempting to compete with AST. In the future, it is possible AST eats at Starlinks core market and viceversa, but thats down the road. So how many satellites does ASTS have in space? ZERO, with plans to launch their first sometime in the month of September. They have BW3. Which is a test satellite, I admit. But it did earn revenue from a gov contract. It is also the sane size as the current production satellites, but with 10x less processing bandwidth. It will assist in providing commercial services, though. But to say they have no satelllites is misleading because it implies we dont even know if their current model will work. It will. Starlinkl has over 5,000 satellites already in space that are fully operational and being used by consumers. Yes, for stationary wifi. Not cellular service. If youre thesis were true, Comcast wouldve bankrupted Verizon and ATT. But we all know that wasnt what happened. Even if you account for the D2C Starlink V2 minis, there are only around 100 with maybe 20 beams each? AST sats have 5600 each. They may only be launching 5 sats, but sat count ignores sat capabilities. ASTS will have a dilution fairly soon to raise further capital and will leave retail investors holding heavy bags. The stock skyrocketed specifically because they stated no more dilution in 2024 and probably none in 2025 as they target prepayments and ExIm financing. Currently it costs about 20m per sat, launch included. Prepayments from Voda, Verizon, and Att now average 4m, 20m, and 5m per sat respectively give or take conditional on successful launch, operation, and FCC approval, all of which are imminent. And that is only 3 of about 40 MNO partners contributing. Currently, if they did 5050 debtprepayment, each MNO would only have to prepay 400k per sat if they take 2 years to build with Opex at 120m per year. And why would MNO want to pay for the sats? Because thats a small price to pay for global coverage, no dead zones, reduced tower costs, improved service, emergency service for disasters, especially when you get half the ARPU. The list goes on. Sorry, but your estimation is ignorant of the reality of the situation. The price will vary a lot over the next two years, but at the end of the day, they now have a service that works, a product to launch, and 40 of the largest telecoms on Earth who want them to succeed, nevermind the US military. Edit just a note on my math 85 sats20msat120m opex32.060B40 mno85 sats2300ksat. I forgot how my napkin math earlier worked out to 400k, I had a reason, but didnt write it down.

This is riddled with innacurate info. Without digging too deep, the first 5 sats will provide coast to coast coverage. It just will not be continuous. They need 20 sats, not 60 to provide continuous coverage in the continental US. Also comparison to starlinks existing sats is kind of silly because they serve different markets. Starlinks core business is coverage to ground units, not existing cell phones. There is no overlap. Starlink is trying, with much difficulty, to break into d2d market, but you cannot use their existing, nond2d sat numbers as having any bearing on that effort.

In their earnings call they stated they do not want to use dilution to raise capital and instead use prepaid agreements with partners like ATT etc to be their primary source of capital generation. They stated diluting the stock will be a disservice to shareholders and so they dont plan on doing so.
Call roaring kitty brother.

Starlink Regenerative architecture, onboard 4G LTE eNB low area spectral efficiency, SISO no US regulatory OK. Problems with interference. Weak narrow midband SISO. Frequent handovers, low orbital lifetime, many sats. Adopted patch on 4G tech onto an architecture built for VSAT internet. Few MNO partners. AST Transparent architecture, terrestrial Nokia 5G gNB, medium area spectral efficiency, regulatory OK. Many patents and superior tech assures no problem with interference. Wide swaths of partner spectrum High penetration lowband, later also midband and cband MIMO, few handovers, few sats, high orbital lifetime. Built from first pribciples for 3GPO 5G and 6G. Many MNO partners 50, with 3 billion subs
Starlink is not competitor to ASTS. Complete different type of service. Dont compare apples to peanuts. No dilution this year.

Oh Lord, valuing a pre revenue stock with PE ratios..... SpaceX has 5000 satelites, but not for direct to cell. SpaceX just wants to get the FCC to weaken their rules for their direct to cell satellites, because their tech is shit and they arent able to get it done within the rules. ASTS has done it within the rules, FCC granted an Experimental License. And yes, you are betting on future income here with ASTS. When their satellites are up there, they have minimal costs for their WORLDWIDE service. Their profit margin is expected to be 90. They have MNOs with partners, that have 3 billion clients. So how much is it worth to have connection everywhere, on the sea, even in an airplane. Lets say only 200 million of the clients are willing to pay 5 usd a month, and ASTS gets 50, then thats 500 million revenue per month and with their profit margin lets say just 250 million profit PER MONTH. So lets say 3 billion profit a year and a PE Ratio of 20, thats 60 billion market cap or 250300 stock price. Ah, and we havent even talked aboud DoD contracts. ASTS already got a small DoD contract 900k, but its also just a test Satellite up there right now. Dilution wont be needed. If a MoU wants a commercial Agreement, they need to make prepayments like ATT did. Together with the revenue comming 2025 they have enough cash to get the next 2030 sattelites up there and then they will be cash flow positive.

investors claim of triple digits soon Yeah, a minority of mostly delusional investors. This rise can be attributed to months of great news, huge derisking, MNO agreements, delivery of satellites and a launch schedulednfor early September. This valuation is basically going off the potential, not the present, valuation. Is it a bit high? Maybe. It might start settling after launch, once the dust has settled you could see a major pull back as people take profits, but nobody trades based off what a PRE REVENUE COMPANY is worth today, its the potential. That being said, this is very uninformed DD. Starlink is a competitor, but to say they have 5000 satellites, as if they are all capable of D2D, is misleading. They are in a stalemate and unless they convince the FCC to lax their permitted interference levels, they wont be launching their service anytime soon. This can go either way and we will have to see what the verdict is. ASTS will be worth 100share in 2 years, probably sooner. Assuming no disasters with launch and unfurling.

I do not agree with your reasons but i do agree with the outcome. The whole point of ASTS is that it has a patented technology for the signal to reach mobile phones without any additional equipment other than your phone as a receiver. Starlink needs additional receiver that is klunky and ugly AF. Also, the business model of ASTS is smart, they will be offering their service through already established carriers, so they dont need to build up the distribution of their product. People will just have an additional option on their already existing mobile phone bill if they want to pay extra for global coverage and that will go to ASTS. Also, you cannot value a prerevenue company on a balance sheet data, are you dumb? That being said. Dilution is very likely if not certain. The durability of satelites is questionable, given just their sheer size largest sats ever put up to enable the transmission and especially signal receiving from earth, if there is any issue with space debree and one of the initial 5 is down, it could mean disaster. Global coverage is VERY VERY far away. And lastly are we sure EVERYONE is going to want to pay more for this fabled global coverage? Like, a grandma in maine is going to pay extra for this service? How many places are actually not covered by the existing 4g network already? Not that many actually. So ASTS is being priced as if the global adoption is a given, when in reality it could be that only adventurers and outdoors people will use the service. That is not a very huge market that would justify putting up 60 satelites in space to service their needs unless the subscription is priced hundreds of dollars per month which means even fewer people using it, meaning their revenues will likely be way lower than what we think today, and profitability might not ever be achieved. So yeah, id value this as a 1.21.6 billion market cap company atm. Definitely not 10b where its going currently.

I think youre responding to the wrong guy. The guy I responded to was talking about productivity. Edit apparently I did use the word productivity. Though I was honestly thinking in a longer time frame than the last six months, which I think is obvious from my comments. I was talking about inventory levels and CHIPSIRA spend winding down which matches the subindicators to the ISM PMI survey the actual report is here as opposed to just the headline and the details often matter more, imo. Inventories and order backlogs are quite low, as is employment, but delivery lags are rising, indicating orders outpacing production. Exports are stable, despite how strong the dollar has been, which bodes well for additional exports as the dollar comes off a bit vs. Euro, Yen, etc. On top of that, you have to go back a bit and look at the baselines from COVID and the WFH pressure wage inflation is sticky its harder to push back down than commodity inflation even moreso now with Chinas economy being so weak and unattractive for offshoring. Consumer spending has been quite resilient largely because of that, while inflation in other sectors excluding housing, which is an interest rates zoning laws story have come back down. All of that still points to a gardenvariety correction, sector rebalancing, and soft landing. But, as I said, the softness does depend on how aggressively the Fed cuts.

Here is a rundown of policy differences. This is not an endorsement.Mr. Trump recently stated that he supports reducing the top corporate income tax bracketfrom 21% to 15% in order to help companies like PATH to compete strongly against foreigncompetitors. 7 years ago, Mr. Trump spearheaded reducing the rate from 35% to 21%.Ms. Harris proposes increasing the top corporate rate from 21% to 28%, a 25% increase inincome tax PATH would have to pay instead of investing in it's growth.Mr. Trump wants to maintain the current long-term capital gains tax on sales of PATH stockat 15% and 20% for higher earners.Ms. Harris proposes taxing capital gains taxes as ordinary earnings. So an investor in the 28% marginal income tax bracket would see in increase in capital gains taxes on PATH stock sales from 15% to 28%, almost doubling the tax owed. Ms. Harris also proposes, with Mr. Biden,to impose the tax on "unrealized" gains, on PATH stock that an investor owns but has not yetsold. The unrealized gain tax would be imposed on higher earners.Mr. Trump lowered personal income tax brackets across the board in 2017. Those reductions will "sunset" (end) in 2025 if they are not renewed. Mr. Trump wants to renew them. Ms. Harris avoids the subject, but Mr. Biden has expressed disdain for the 2017 reductions. The increased standard deduction would also sunset. If the brackets sunset and increase to the pre-2017 levels, so too would the cap-gains tax with Harris's proposal.

Two separate issues being the performance of the ETF and the PATH stock.  PATH's total addressable market and competitive position lends itself as having good long-term investment potential.  On the other hand, ARKK's investment thesis and logic is flawed and has been proven to be flawed over the past few years.  Having very young and inexperienced analysts evaluate potential disruptive technology companies while these companies are young, and unprofitable has proven to be outside their zone of expertise.  They have sold numerous winners before they have taken off and rode the losers down to practically nothing.  Some of these losers were their most high conviction picks such as TDOC, DNA, etc.  She may see a rebound with lower interest rates but its pretty obvious they are swimming in the wrong pond.

Cathie Wood's ARK Innovation ETF fund has lost -75% since its peak in 2021 and continues to hold its sizable PATH position when prudent portfolio managers would be cutting the PATH position by at least 50%. Risk volatility of ARK ETF fund is at an all-time high.  The next two QTR reporting actuals will provide clarity on both PATH and ARK ETF performance.

PATH's actual reported quarterly revenue for the 1/30/24 period was $405 million, while the 4/30/24 period dropped to $335 million and -18% QTR decline.  With likely limited new base revenue growth ahead for PATH and no "Net Income" being produced, the current $7 Billion market cap valuation is due for a major hair trimming with the next QTR financial report.  Combine it with an overall softening of the overvalued Software/SaaS sector, PATH's SP has significant risk over next several quarters.  PATH's high RPA product pricing and potential customer churn is also a risk factor.
